z:row.TitlePrimary: Multipass beam breakup in energy recovery linacs
z:row.Keyword: energy recovery|recirculating linacs|instabilities|beam breakup|free electron lasers|radio frequency|Instruments & Instrumentation|Nuclear Science & Technology|Physics, Particles & Fields|Spectroscopy
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Nuclear Instruments & Methods in Physics Research Section A-Accelerators Spectrometers Detectors and Associated Equipment
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: AMSTERDAM; PO BOX 211, 1000 AE AMSTERDAM, NETHERLANDS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Thomas Jefferson Natl Accelerator Facil, Newport News, VA 23606 USA. Synchrotron Radiat Ctr, Stoughton, WI 53589 USA. Japan Atom Energy Res Inst, Tokai, Ibaraki 3191195, Japan. WW Hansen Expt Lab, Stanford, CA 94305 USA.; Pozdeyev, E, Thomas Jef(TRUNCATED)
z:row.Abstract: This paper is a compilation of several presentations on multipass beam breakup (BBU) in energy recovery linacs (ERLs) given at the 32nd Advanced ICFA Beam Workshop on ERLs. The goal of this paper is to summarize the progress achieved in analytical, numerical, and experimental studies of the instability and outline available and proposed BBU mitigation techniques. In this paper, a simplified theory of multipass BBU in recirculating linacs is presented. Several BBU suppression techniques and their working principles are discussed. The paper presents an overview of available BBU codes. Results of experimental studies of multipass BBU at the Jefferson Laboratory (JLab) FEL Upgrade are described. (c) 2005 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

z:row.TitlePrimary: First measurements and observations from the new permanent magnet undulator at the SRC
z:row.Keyword: Instruments & Instrumentation|Physics, Applied
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: MELVILLE; CIRCULATION & FULFILLMENT DIV, 2 HUNTINGTON QUADRANGLE, STE 1 N O 1, MELVILLE, NY 11747-4501 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Synchrotron Radiat, Stoughton, WI 53589 USA.; Wallace, DJ, Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Synchrotron Radiat, 3731 Schneider Dr, Stoughton, WI 53589 USA.
z:row.Abstract: In December of 2000 the University of Wisconsin Synchrotron Radiation Center (SRC) installed a new, state-of-the-art undulator in long straight section 2 of the Aladdin storage ring. This undulator replaced the first Aladdin undulator, which was on loan from the Stanford Synchrotron Radiation Laboratory and had been in use since 1986 [K. Halbach , IEEE Trans. Nucl. Sci. NS-28, 3136 (1981); H. Winick , Nucl. Instrum. Methods Phys. Res. A 208, 127 (1983); M. A. Green , Nucl. Instrum. Methods Phys. Res. A 266, 91 (1988)]. The new undulator was designed, constructed, and tested by Danfysik (Danfysik A/S, Moellchaves 31A, DK-4040 Jyllinge, Denmark). The undulator uses NdFeB permanent magnets for the magnetic structure and is 3.52 m long with 50 periods, each of 68.3 mm. The new undulator is intended to provide high flux from 7.8 to 500 eV. To cover this wide energy range we use the first through ninth odd harmonics. The magnetic structure has been phase-corrected to better than 2degrees rms and should provide fidelity better than 90% through the ninth harmonic. The resulting undulator flux will support an extreme ultraviolet nano-lithography beamline, a low energy Wadsworth beam line, and a high energy VLS-PGM beam line. Some coherence experiments are also anticipated. The undulator radiation has been analyzed using an existing HTM [M. C. Hettrick, Nucl. Instrum. Methods Phys. Res. A 266, 404 (1988)] monochromator, a durable filter-pinhole detector, and computer controlled, cooled, scanning apertures. We present measurements of the undulator harmonic content, energy and spatial structure of the undulator beam, and undulator beam position stability. (C) 2002 American Institute of Physics.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: BISOGNANO JJ, 2001, P PART ACC C CHIC IL DELRIO MS, 1998, P SOC PHOTO-OPT INS, V3448, P340 GREEN MA, 1994, NUCL INSTRUM METH A, V347, P568 GREEN MA, 2001, P PART ACC C CHIC IL; NR: 4; TC: 0; J9: REV SCI INSTR; PN: Part 2; PG: 4; GA: 527JK

z:row.TitlePrimary: Current status of the Synchrotron Radiation Center
z:row.Keyword: UNDULATOR|ALADDIN|SRC|Instruments & Instrumentation|Physics, Applied
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: MELVILLE; CIRCULATION & FULFILLMENT DIV, 2 HUNTINGTON QUADRANGLE, STE 1 N O 1, MELVILLE, NY 11747-4501 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Synchrotron Radiat, Stoughton, WI 53589 USA.; Moore, CJ, Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Synchrotron Radiat, 3731 Schneider Dr, Stoughton, WI 53589 USA.
z:row.Abstract: The Synchrotron Radiation Center operates the Aladdin electron storage ring at energies of 800 meV or 1 GeV in support of a broad range of national and international research programs with a major focus on the study of valence electrons, spectromicroscopy, and nanolithography. Upgrades to the storage ring have improved the stability of the source, and experiments with low emittance lattice configurations show the feasibility of increased brightness for new or enhanced research. Three recently installed undulators, two pure permanent magnet devices and an electromagnetic device, and the associated instrumentation offer experimentalists high flux combined with high resolution. The status of the existing instrumentation, recent scientific results, and an overview of plans for new undulator-based instruments to cover the photon energy range from 7.8 to 400+ eV will be presented. (C) 2002 American Institute of Physics.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Approaches to lowering emittance in existing light sources
z:row.Keyword: emittance|synchrotron|radiation|Instruments & Instrumentation|Nuclear Science & Technology|Physics, Particles & Fields|Spectroscopy
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Nuclear Instruments & Methods in Physics Research Section A-Accelerators Spectrometers Detectors and Associated Equipment
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: AMSTERDAM; PO BOX 211, 1000 AE AMSTERDAM, NETHERLANDS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Synchrotron Radiat, Stoughton, WI 53589 USA.; Bisognano, JJ, Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Synchrotron Radiat, 3731 Schneider Dr, Stoughton, WI 53589 USA.
z:row.Abstract: Emittance reduction remains a singular goal for the synchrotron light community. The many tools available to achieve better phase space performance are described, and their successful application to existing facilities is highlighted. The demonstration of a factor of three emittance reduction with good lifetime for the Aladdin storage is discussed as a detailed example of the interplay of a variety of beam performance issues. (C) 2001 Published by Elsevier Science B.V.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: *LBL, 1986, LBL PUB, V5172 BECK U, P 1999 PART ACC C, P206 BLUM EB, P 1999 PART ACC C, P2304 BOSCH RA, 1997, LOW EMITTANCE LATTIC CORBET J, 1999, SYNCHROTRON RAD NEWS, V12, P25 JACKSON A, P 1997 PART ACC C, P703 KATOH M, P 1998 EUR PART ACC, P590 LEBLANC G, 2000, IN PRESS P 2000 EUR ROPERT A, P 1997 PART ACC C, P754 STREUN A, SLSTMETA19990014 PSI WEIHRETER E, 1999, SYNCHROTRON RAD NEWS, V12, P16 WIEDEMAN H, 1993, PARTICLE ACCELERATOR; NR: 12; TC: 0; J9: NUCL INSTRUM METH PHYS RES A; PN: Part 1; PG: 5; GA: 470YR

z:row.TitlePrimary: Instrumentation for a new undulator at SRC
z:row.Keyword: Wadsworth|monochromator|PLANE GRATING MONOCHROMATOR|ALADDIN|Instruments & Instrumentation|Nuclear Science & Technology|Physics, Particles & Fields|Spectroscopy
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Nuclear Instruments & Methods in Physics Research Section A-Accelerators Spectrometers Detectors and Associated Equipment
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: AMSTERDAM; PO BOX 211, 1000 AE AMSTERDAM, NETHERLANDS
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Synchrotron Radiat, Stoughton, WI 53589 USA.; Severson, M, Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Synchrotron Radiat, 3731 Schneider Dr, Stoughton, WI 53589 USA.
z:row.Abstract: A new permanent magnet undulator will soon be installed in long straight section two (LSS2) of the Aladdin storage ring. We report on design characteristics of the undulator and beamlines that will utilize the first through ninth harmonics to cover the energy range from 7.8 to 500eV. The instrumentation design is to provide high flux with moderate resolution throughout this range through the installation of two monochromators, as well as support a EUV experimental lithography exposure station. The first monochromator will be a Wadsworth design covering the energy ran-e from 7.8 to 50 eV with <10 meV resolution. The second will be a grazing incidence monochromator covering the energy range from 50 to 500 eV with <80 meV resolution up to 400 eV. Both of these monochromators will deliver high flux into a small spot size at the sample position. Diverting mirrors will allow users to select the proper beam path for each monochromator or EUV exposure station thus matching the wavelength region to the intended experiment. (C) 2001 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.
z:row.Notes: PT: J; CR: AMEMIYA K, 1996, J SYNCHROTRON RADI 6, V3, P282 EDWARDS DF, 1985, HDB OPTICAL CONSTANT FISHER MV, 1996, P SOC PHOTO-OPT INS, V2856, P212 GREEN MA, 1988, NUCL INSTRUM METH A, V266, P91 HELLWEGE KH, 1937, Z PHYS, V106, P588 JARK W, 1992, REV SCI INSTRUM 2B, V63, P1241 KUBALA T, 2000, AIP C P, V417, P91 MOSSESSIAN DA, 1996, REV SCI INSTRUM, V67, P1 OLSON CG, 1994, NUCL INSTRUM METH A, V347, P278 REININGER R, 1994, NUCL INSTRUM METH A, V347, P304 SEVERSON M, 2000, AIP C P, V417, P95 SOLAK HH, 2000, AIP C P, V417, P99 WADSWORTH FLO, 1896, ASTROPHYS J, V3, P47 WALKER RP, 1992, REV SCI INSTRUM, V63, P392 YOUNGER FC, 1994, NUCL INSTRUM METH A, V347, P98; NR: 15; TC: 2; J9: NUCL INSTRUM METH PHYS RES A; PN: Part 1; PG: 4; GA: 470YR

z:row.TitlePrimary: Robinson instabilities with a higher-harmonic cavity
z:row.Keyword: DOUBLE RF-SYSTEM|LANDAU|Physics, Nuclear|Physics, Particles & Fields
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Physical Review Special Topics-Accelerators and Beams
z:row.PlaceOfPublication: COLLEGE PK; ONE PHYSICS ELLIPSE, COLLEGE PK, MD 20740-3844 USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Synchrotron Radiat, Stoughton, WI 53589 USA.; Bosch, RA, Univ Wisconsin, Ctr Synchrotron Radiat, 3731 Schneider Dr, Stoughton, WI 53589 USA.
z:row.Abstract: A radio frequency system with a fourth-harmonic "Landau" cavity suppresses coupled-bunch instabilities and increases the beam lifetime of the Aladdin electron storage ring. When the storage ring is operated with a small momentum compaction, instabilities limit the utility of the Landau cavity. Analytical modeling of instability frequencies and growth rates, simulations, and experiments suggest that the observed instabilities result from coupling between dipole and quadrupole Robinson modes.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Current status of the Synchrotron Radiation Center
z:row.TitleSecondary: Eighth International Conference on Synchrotron Radiation Instrumentation, 25-29 Aug. 2003
z:row.Keyword: accelerator magnets|electron accelerators|electron beams|particle beam diagnostics|particle beam stability|permanent magnets|storage rings|synchrotron radiation|wigglers|X-ray monochromators|X-ray production
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Synchrotron Radiat. Center, Wisconsin Univ., Stoughton, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Synchrotron Radiation Center (SRC) operates the Aladdin electron storage ring at energies of 800 MeV or 1 GeV in support of a broad range of national and international research programs. A low emittance configuration is in routine operation during 800-MeV shifts and offers improved photon flux density with about the same beam lifetime. An improved undulator compensation algorithm and new optical beam position monitors have been implemented improving beam stability and maintaining vertical beam size variations to < 2% peak-to-peak during undulator scanning. Instrumentation initiatives include construction of a modified Wadsworth beamline (7.8 - 50 eV) and a variable-line-spacing plane-grating monochromator (VLS-PGM, 75 - 2000 eV) to utilize radiation from a permanent magnet undulator. The Wadsworth beamline is being commissioned for photoelectron spectroscopy (PES) experiments using high-resolution Scienta analyzers. The VLS-PGM is being constructed for experiments that require higher photon energies and high flux density such as X-ray photoemission electron microscopy (X-PEEM) and X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS). It is scheduled to be available in early 2004. Recent research at the SRC has produced exciting results in a variety of fields, culminating in eight articles published in Physical Review Letters and three in Nature since October 2002, in addition to articles in many other publications. An outreach program offers research experiences for undergraduates and provides the general public with an awareness of synchrotron radiation. Hands-on workshops and activities on FTIR microscopy and X-PEEM are offered for graduate students and scientists. SRC sponsors a summer Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program and offers opportunities to non-research universities and high schools. Tours and educational events are coordinated with local civic groups and schools. Open houses are offered that include tours, demonstrations, and family activities
z:row.User2: Synchrotron Radiation Center; Aladdin electron storage ring; low emittance configuration; improved photon flux density; beam lifetime; undulator compensation algorithm; optical beam position monitors; beam stability; vertical beam size variations; undulator scanning; modified Wadsworth beamline; variable-line-spacing plane-grating monochromator; permanent magnet undulator; photoelectron spectroscopy experiments; high-resolution Scienta analyzers; VLS-PGM; photon energies; hands-on workshops; hands-on activities; FTIR microscopy; X-PEEM; X-ray photoemission electron microscopy; X-ray absorption spectroscopy; XAS; Research Experience for Undergraduates program; REU program; 800 MeV; 1 GeV; 7.8 to 50 eV; 75 to 2000 eV

z:row.TitlePrimary: Robinson modes at Aladdin
z:row.TitleSecondary: PAC 2003 - Proceedings of the 2003 IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference, May 12-16 2003
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
z:row.Keyword: Light|Charged particles|Light emission|Synchrotron radiation|Harmonic analysis|Approximation theory|Mathematical models|Computer simulation
z:row.Publisher: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc., Piscataway, United States
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Synchrotron Radiation Center, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States
z:row.Abstract: A fourth harmonic radiofrequency (RF) cavity improves the beam lifetime of the Aladdin electron storage ring. When the harmonic cavity is operated with a lowemittance lattice, coupling between the dipole and quadrupole Robinson modes may cause instability. During stable operation, damped Robinson modes are observed in the spectrum of phase noise upon the beam.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Harmonic radiofrequency; Harmonic cavity; Phase noise

z:row.TitlePrimary: Insertion device commissioning at SRC
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of 2001 Particle Accelerator Conference, 18-22 June 2001
z:row.TitleTertiary: PACS2001. Proceedings of the 2001 Particle Accelerator Conference (Cat. No.01CH37268)
z:row.Keyword: electron accelerators|particle beam injection|particle beam stability|storage rings|wigglers
z:row.Abstract: The Synchrotron Radiation Center (SRC) has been installing undulators on its 1-GeV electron storage ring, Aladdin, over the last 15 years. Commissioning these devices is subject to fairly demanding requirements related to the needs of the user community. A number of topics are discussed, including injection, trim-control, steering correction, beam size stabilization, and lifetime preservation. Experiences, problems, and solutions are presented from both machine and beamline aspects
z:row.Notes: Also available on CD-ROM in PDF format
z:row.User2: SRC; Synchrotron Radiation Center; Aladdin; undulators; injection; trim-control; steering correction; beam size stabilization; lifetime

z:row.TitlePrimary: Influence of the momentum compaction upon Landau cavity stability
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
z:row.Keyword: Storage rings|Electron beams|Natural frequencies|Synchrotrons|Compaction|Damping|Computer simulation
z:row.Publisher: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Synchrotron Radiation Center, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States
z:row.Abstract: A fourth-harmonic "Landau" radiofrequency (RF) cavity suppresses coupled bunch instabilities and increases the beam lifetime of the Aladdin electron storage ring. When the storage ring is operated with a small momentum compaction, instabilities limit the utility of the Landau cavity. Analytic modeling and simulations suggest that instabilities result from fast mode-coupling between the dipole and quadrupole Robinson modes.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

z:row.TitlePrimary: Operation of Aladdin at lowered emittance
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
z:row.Keyword: Storage rings|Synchrotron radiation|Light sources|Particle beam bunching|Photons|Photodiodes|Charge coupled devices
z:row.Publisher: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Synchrotron Radiation Center, University of Wisconsin-Madison, Stoughton, WI 53589, United States
z:row.Abstract: To increase the available photon flux density for users, alternate lattice tunings of the Aladdin synchrotron light source have been developed with horizontal emittances significantly lower than the present value of 127 π nm-rad. Reduction of the horizontal emittance by a factor of three has been obtained experimentally. When the fourth harmonic Landau cavity is used to lengthen the bunch, the observed beam lifetime with the new lattice is not significantly changed from that of the existing lattice. The present goal is to achieve a factor of four horizontal and a factor of two vertical emittance reduction routinely. Progress in making this new configuration fully operational is discussed, including the use of quadrupole shunts with correction software for betafunction and dispersion correction, understanding of a mode coupling instability in higher-harmonic RF systems, RF clearing of ions, and fabrication of new optical monitoring stations.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved

We report on design characteristics of the undulator and beamlines that will utilize the first through ninth harmonics to cover the energy range from 7.8 to 500 eV. z:row.TitlePrimary: A status report on the development of a high power UV and IR FEL at CEBAF
z:row.TitleSecondary: Free Electron Lasers. Seventeenth International Free Electron Conference, 21-25 Aug. 1995
z:row.TitleTertiary: Nucl. Instrum. Methods Phys. Res. A, Accel. Spectrom. Detect. Assoc. Equip. (Netherlands)
z:row.Keyword: free electron lasers|infrared spectra|laser cavity resonators|particle beam stability|ultraviolet spectra
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Nuclear Instruments & Methods in Physics Research, Section A (Accelerators, Spectrometers, Detectors and Associated Equipment)
z:row.Abstract: Previously we presented a design for a kiloWatt demonstration industrial UV FEL. Progress has been made in resolving several design issues identified in that work. More exact simulations of the injector have resulted in a better estimate of the injector performance. A more compact lattice has been designed meeting the design requirements for the UV FEL, and a new design point has been studied which greatly increases the threshold for longitudinal instabilities. A stability analysis of the RF control system has found that only minor modifications from existing CEBAF controls will be necessary to allow them to be used with a high-current, energy-recovery accelerator. Designs for the optical cavity length and figure systems have been conceptualized and a model of the corner-cube resonator is being built and tested. Finally, three-dimensional simulations of the FEL have been carried out which show that the laser should exceed its minimum design goals for average power
z:row.User2: status report; high power FEL; UV FEL; IR FEL; FEL design; electron beam injector; compact lattice; longitudinal instabilities; stability analysis; RF control system; optical cavity length; corner-cube resonator; FEL simulation

z:row.TitlePrimary: A proposed high-power UV industrial demonstration laser at CEBAF
z:row.TitleSecondary: Lasers as Tools for Manufacturing of Durable Goods and Microelectronics, 29 Jan.-2 Feb. 1996
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proc. SPIE - Int. Soc. Opt. Eng. (USA)
z:row.Keyword: accelerator cavities|free electron lasers|laser cavity resonators|laser materials processing|laser reliability|micromachining|optical losses|surface treatment
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Proceedings of the SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Continuous Electron Beam Accel. Facility, Newport News, VA, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Laser Processing Consortium, a collaboration of industries, universities, and the Continuous Electron Beam Accelerator Facility (CEBAF) in Newport News, Virginia, has proposed building a demonstration industrial processing laser for surface treatment and micromachining. The laser is a free-electron laser (FEL) with average power output exceeding 1 kW in the ultraviolet (UV). The design calls for a novel driver accelerator that recovers most of the energy of the exhaust electron beam to produce laser light with good wall-plug efficiency. The laser and accelerator design use technologies that are scalable to much higher power. We describe critical design issues for the laser such as the optical resonator stability, power handling, and losses, and the electron beam quality, power, and reliability. We also describe the calculated laser performance. Finally, progress to date on accelerator development and resonator modeling is reported
z:row.User2: UV industrial demonstration laser; CEBAF; Laser Processing Consortium; industrial processing laser; surface treatment; micromachining; free-electron laser; power output; ultraviolet laser; driver accelerator; exhaust electron beam; laser light; efficiency; laser design; accelerator design; optical resonator stability; optical resonator power handling; optical resonator losses; electron beam reliability; electron beam power; electron beam quality; resonator modeling

z:row.TitlePrimary: Accelerator design for the high-power industrial FEL
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1995 16th IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference. Part 1 (of 5), May 1-5 1995
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
z:row.Keyword: Linear accelerators|High power lasers|Free electron lasers|Superconducting devices
z:row.Abstract: We have developed a conceptual design for an industrial-use kilowatt UV and IR FEL driven by a recirculating, energy-recovering 200 MeV, 1-5 mA superconducting rf (SRF) electron accelerator. In this paper we describe the accelerator design of this FEL. The accelerator consists of a 10 MeV injector, a 96 MeV SRF linac with a two-pass transport which accelerates the beam to 200 MeV, followed by energy-recovery deceleration through two passes to the dump. Technical challenges include high-intensity injector development, multi-pass energy-recovery operation, SRF modifications and control for FEL operation, development of tuneable, nearly-isochronous, large-acceptance transports, and matching of the beam to the FEL wiggler. An overview of the accelerator design is presented.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Superconducting radiofrequency electron accelerator; Energy recovery deceleration

z:row.TitlePrimary: Design of a high charge CW photocathode injector test stand at CEBAF
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1995 16th Particle Accelerator Conference. Part 2 (of 5), May 1-5 1995
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
z:row.Keyword: Particle injectors|Photocathodes|Particle accelerators|Cryogenic equipment|Particle beam injection|Electron guns|Light emission|Electrodes|Semiconducting gallium arsenide|Particle beam dynamics|Calculations|Algorithms|Mathematical models
z:row.Abstract: A 10 MeV high-charge CW electron injector test stand has been designed for the CEBAF UV FEL driver accelerator. It consists of a 500 kV DC photocathode gun, a 1500 MHz room-temperature buncher, a modified CEBAF cryounit (quarter cryomodule) with an SRF accelerating gradient of approx.10 MV/m, two solenoids in the 500 kV region and an achromatic, non-isochronous injection transport line delivering 10 MeV beam to the driver accelerator. Experimental work is in progress toward establishing design system performance.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Photocathode injector test; Room temperature buncher; Cryounit; Accelerating gradient; Injection transport line; Photoemission gun; Negative electron affinity

z:row.TitlePrimary: A high-average-power FEL for industrial applications
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of the 1995 Particle Accelerator Conference (Cat. No.95CH35843)
z:row.Keyword: accelerator RF systems|ceramics|electron accelerators|free electron lasers|metals|micromachining|polymers|surface treatment
z:row.Abstract: CEBAF has developed a comprehensive conceptual design of an industrial user facility based on a kilowatt UV (150-1000 nm) and IR (2-25 micron) FEL driven by a recirculating, energy-recovering 200 MeV superconducting radio-frequency (SRF) accelerator. FEL users-CEBAF's partners in the Laser Processing Consortium, including AT&T, DuPont, IBM, Northrop-Grumman, 3M, and Xerox-plan to develop applications such as polymer surface processing, metals and ceramics micromachining, and metal surface processing, with the overall effort leading to later scale-up to industrial systems at 50-100 kW. Representative applications are described. The proposed high-average-power FEL overcomes limitations of conventional laser sources in available power, cost-effectiveness, tunability and pulse structure
z:row.User2: high-average-power FEL; industrial applications; CEBAF; conceptual design; industrial user facility; UV FEL; IR FEL; recirculating superconducting RF accelerator; energy-recovering radiofrequency accelerator; polymer surface processing; metals micromachining; ceramics micromachining; metal surface processing; tunability; pulse structure; free electron laser; 2 to 25 mum; 200 MeV; 150 to 1000 nm; 50 to 100 kW

z:row.TitlePrimary: Alignment of CEBAF cryomodules
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1993 Particle Accelerator Conference. Part 4 (of 5), May 17-20 1993
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings of the IEEE Particle Accelerator Conference
z:row.Keyword: Alignment|Cavity resonators|Electron beams|Particle accelerators|Cryogenics|Installation|Assembly|Errors|Performance|Fits and tolerances|Standards
z:row.Publisher: Publ by IEEE, Piscataway, NJ, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Continuous Electron Beam Accelerator Facility, Newport News, VA, USA
z:row.Abstract: CEBAF, the Continuous Electron Beam Accelerator Facility, when completed, will house a 4 GeV recirculating accelerator. Each of the accelerator's two linacs contains 160 superconducting radio frequency (SRF) 1497 MHz niobium cavities [1] in 20 cryomodules. Alignment of the cavities within the cryomodule with respect to beam axis is critical to achieving the optimum accelerator performance. This paper discusses the rationale for the current specification on cavity mechanical alignment: 2 mrad (rms) applied to the 0.5 m active length cavities. We describe the tooling that was developed to achieved the tolerance at the time of cavity pair assembly, to preserve and integrate alignment during cryomodule assembly, and to translate the alignment to appropriate installation in the beam line.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Continuous electron beam accelerator facility; Superconducting radio frequency; Cryomodules; Current specification; Cavity mechanical alignment; Cavity fringe fields
